cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 60 (Thursday, April 6, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Ms. TENNEY:H.R. 2539.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8The single subject of this legislation is:This bill would make the New Markets Tax Credit programpermanent.[Page H1712]

item.title: New Markets Tax Credit Extension Act of 2023

latestAction.text: Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Subcommittee on Housing, Transportation, and Community Development. Hearings held.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

cdata.text:
New Markets Tax Credit Extension Act of 2023

This bill makes the new markets tax credit permanent. It also modifies the credit to (1) provide for an inflation adjustment to the limitation amount for the credit after 2023, and (2) allow an offset against the alternative minimum tax for the credit (determined with respect to qualified equity investments initially made after 2022).

bill.title: New Markets Tax Credit Extension Act of 2023

item.title: New Markets Tax Credit Extension Act of 2023
New Markets Tax Credit Extension Act of 2023
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to permanently extend the new markets tax credit, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
